newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Polynesian Airlines lifts yr profit to NZ$1.25 mln.
newsitem.headline: Polynesian Airlines lifts yr profit to NZ$1.25 mln.

text.p: Western Samoa's national carrier Polynesian Airlines on Friday posted an audited net profit after abnormal items and tax of WS$2.1 million (NZ$1.25 million) for the year to June 30, 1996.
This was up on the 1994/95 profit of WS$900,000.

Chairman Tuilaepa Sa'ilele Malielegaoi said the difficulties experienced in 1993 and 1994 were now firmly in the past and Polynesian Airlines was focused on enhancing its reputation as a reliable, innovative and profitable regional Pacific carrier.
The net profit was achieved on revenues of WS$62.2 million and the airline had not had to call on the shareholder or financial markets for any funding.
"This healthy cash position enabled Polynesian to self fund the outright purchase of an additional Twin Otter aircraft in 1995/96," the airline said.

Polynesian would move to introduce further products and services in 1996/97 in cooperation with its alliance partner, Air New Zealand, and interline carriers which operate into and within the Pacific.
The extension of a weekly Honolulu code share service through to Los Angeles in November 1996 was one such development.
